root.para: Traded financial instruments typically are maintained in electronic form and street name and, accordingly, cannot be inspected. For example, even though stock certificates are on file at a depository (for example, the Depository Trust Company), those shares are allocated to broker-dealers, and the issuer has no record of who owns shares. The broker-dealers send documents such as proxy statements to stockholders. Confirmation of the security provides evidence about the existence of financial instruments. Evidence about existence also may be gathered by examining supporting documentation, such as

listitem.para: instructions to portfolio managers or directed custodians.
